conclusion: Understand the relationship between induced EMF and direction of induced current.
Explanation of formula variables: ε is induced EMF, μ₀ is permeability of free space, I is current, L is length of conductor.
Explanation of formula variables: B is magnetic induction intensity, L is length of conductor.
Rod perpendicular to magnetic induction intensity results in induced current I in direction of magnetic induction intensity.
Induced EMF ε is in direction opposite to magnetic induction intensity.
Bent rod into two equal-length and mutually perpendicular segments results in induced current I in direction of magnetic induction intensity.
Induced EMF ε is in direction opposite to magnetic induction intensity for bent rod.
Rod in plane perpendicular to magnetic induction intensity results in induced current I in direction of magnetic induction intensity.
Induced EMF ε is in direction opposite to magnetic induction intensity for rod in plane.
Induced EMF at both ends of rod is ε.
Bent rod results in induced current I in direction of magnetic induction intensity.
Induced EMF ε is in direction opposite to magnetic induction intensity for bent rod.
Rod in plane results in induced current I in direction of magnetic induction intensity.
Induced EMF ε is in direction opposite to magnetic induction intensity for rod in plane.
